Title: Suppose $(a_n)$ is a sequence such that $a_n=\frac{1!+2!+\cdots+n!}{n!}$. Show that $\lim{a_n}=1$
Content: Suppose $(a_n)$ is a sequence such that $$a_n=\frac{1!+2!+\cdots+n!}{n!} \, .$$ Show that $\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty}{a_n}=1$. My attempt is to formulate an inequality and then use the Squeeze Theorem. Since we know that $$\frac{1}{n!}+\frac{2!}{n!}+\cdots+1>1$$ as $\frac{i!}{n!}>0$ for all $1 \leq i \leq n-1$, we have $a_n \geq1$. Then I'm stuck at formulating another side. Can anyone help?
AcceptedAnswer:
Each of $1!,2!,...,(n-2)!$ is at most $(n-2)!$. Since there are $n-2$ such terms you have
$$\frac{1! + 2! + \cdots + n!}{n!} \leq \frac{(n-2)(n-2)! + (n-1)! + n!}{n!}$$
$$= \frac{n-2}{n(n-1)} + \frac{1}{n} + 1$$
The limit of this as $n \rightarrow \infty$ is $1$, which is what you need.
